lg.l: Of the sweet, cool, green translucence,
Till I go where green leaves rustle,
Far from the haunts of men—
Till I leave the city’s bustle
For the depths of Burwood glen. Burwood glen. Likely an area several kilometres south of Newcastle, in what is now the Glenrock State Conservation Area.
The starry daisy Starry daisy. There are over 1,000 species of Asteraceae, or daisy, native to Australia. noddeth
And maiden-hair ferns Maiden-hair ferns. The low growing maidenhair fern is indigenous to New South Wales, and grows in the vicinity of streams. whisper
Which laughing goes and tells them
The gum-trees towering skyward Gum-trees … skyward. Coastal species of eucalypt gum found in New South Wales can grow as high as 70 metres.

The laurel Laurel. There are several indigenous Australian species of laurel, but many of these are tropical trees, and the poem possibly refers to the camphor laurel, which spread rapidly after being introduced in New South Wales in the 1820s. and the wattle Wattle. There are over 1,000 species of acacia, or wattle, that are indigenous to Australia, although most grow in arid or semi-arid regions unlike that described in the poem.
The wild clematis Wild clematis. Most likely the climbing shrub clematis aristate, also known as old man’s beard. twineth
By the cooings of the dove. Dove. There are numerous indigenous Australian species of pigeon, as well as several species introduced in the nineteenth century.
With the sweet, shy flowerets peeping
While they blush at being wakened
By his kisses from their sleep.
The rocks, and trees, and streams;
While his blazing eyes are searching
And give back kiss for kisses,
Till fall the shades of night.
Sweet is thy calm, O Burwood!
In thy Dryad-haunted bowers, Dryad-haunted bowers. The dryad is a wood nymph, according to Greek mythology.
Far from the haunts of men,
I have passed a day of quiet,
I have passed a day of rest;
And from all the things around me
I have drawn some happy zest;
For Nature, there, has shown me

body.p: ALFRED SHARP. Sharp. Sharp. Sharpe began to spell his name without the final “e,” in accordance with the spelling used by his younger brother, William Bethal Sharp, who he joined after his move to Australia.
Newcastle, 1889. Newcastle, 1889. Sharpe had moved to Newcastle, New South Wales, in late 1887.
